Continuance crowns desert, she never can go
For perfect honest that's not always so.
Beshrew thy heart for urging this excuse,
Thou'st justified her somewhat.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Among so many women not one here
Dare swear a simple chastity! here's an age
To propagate virtue in: since I have begun,
I'll shame you all together, and so leave you.
My lord of Kent!

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Though I am your guest today,
And should be less austere to you or yours,
In this case pardon me, I may not spare her.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: Then her own goodness friend her; she comes my lord.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: The tender reputation of a maid
Makes your honour, or else nothing can;
The oath you take is not for truth to man,
But to your own white soul, a mighty task;
What dare you do in this?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: My lord, as much
As chastity can put a woman to,
I ask no favour; and t'approve the purity
Of what my habit and my time professeth;
As likewise to requite all courteous censure,
Here I take oath I am as free from man
As truth from falsehood, or sanctity from slain.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: O thou treasure that ravishes the possessor!
I know not where to speed so well again,
I'll keep thee while I have thee; here's a fountain
To spring forth princes, and the seeds of kingdoms.
Away with that infection of black honour, and those her leprous pledges,
Here will we store succession with true peace,
And of pure virgins grace the poor increase.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ha ha, he's well provided now, here struck my fortunes.
With what an impudent confidence she swore honest,
Having th'advantage of the oath! Precious whore.
Methinks I should not hear from fortune next
under an earldom now; she cannot spend
A night so idly, but to make a lord
With ease methinks and play: the Earl of Kent
Is calm and smooth, like a deep dangerous water;
He has some secret way, I know his blood,
The grave's not greedier, nor hell's lord more proud.
Something will hap; for this astonishing choice
Strikes pale the kingdom, at which I rejoice.

div.stage: Dumb show. Enter Lupus, Germanus, Devonshire, and Stafford, leading Vortimer, and crown him: Vortiger comes to them in passion, they neglect him. Enter Roxena in fury expressing discontent, then they lead out Vortimer; Roxena gives two villains gold to murder him, they swear performance and go with her: Vortiger offers to run on his sword, Horsus prevents him, and persuades him; the lords bring in Vortimer dead; Vortiger mourns and submits to them, they swear him, and crown him. Then enters Hengist with Saxons, Vortiger draws, threatens expulsion, and then sends a parley, which Hengist seems to grant by laying down his weapons, so all depart severally.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Of pagan blood a Queen being chose,
Roxena hight, the Britain's rose
For Vortimer, and crowned him King,
But she soon poisoned that sweet spring.
Then unto rule they did restore
Vortiger, and him they swore
Against the Saxons; they (Constrained)
Begged peace, treaty, and obtained;
And now in numbers equally
Upon the plain near Salisbury,
A peaceful meeting they decreen
Like men of love, no weapon seen.
But Hengist, that ambitious lord,
Full of guile, corrupts his word,
As the sequel too well proves;
On that your eyes, on us your loves.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: If we let slip this opportuneful hour,
Take leave of fortune, certainty, or thought
Of ever fixing; we are loose at root,
And the least storm may rend us from the bosom
Of this lands hopes for ever. But, dear Saxons,
Fasten we now, and our unshaken firmness
Will endure after ages.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Observe you not how Vortiger the King,
Base in submission, threatened our expulsion,
His arm held up against us? Is it not time
To make our best prevention? what should check me?
He has perfected that great work in our daughter,
And made her Queen, she can ascend no higher,
Therefore be quick, dispatch; here, every man
Receive into the service of his vengeance
An instrument of steel, which will unseen
Lurk like a snake under the innocent shade
Of a spred summer-leaf, there fly you on,
Take heart, the commons love us, those removed
That are the nerves, our greatness stands improved.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.p: Give us the word, my lord, and we are perfect.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: That's true, the word, I lose myself. Nemp your sexes.
It shall be that.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: But the king's mine, take heed you touch him not.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: We shall not be at leisure, never fear it,
We shall have work enough of our own, my lord.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: Calm looks but stormy souls possess you all.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: We see you keep your words in all points firm.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: No longer may we beast of so much breath
as goes to a word's making, then of care
In the preserving of it, when 'tis made.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: You're in a virtuous way, my lord of Kent,
And since both sides are met like sons of peace,
All other arms laid by in signs of favour
If our conditions be embraced.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: We'll use no other but these only here.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Follow it to the heart, my trusty Saxons,
It is your liberty, your wealth and honour. Soft, you are mine, my lord.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Take me not basely, when all sense and strength
Lies bound up in amazement at this treachery.
What devil hath breathed this everlasting part
Of falsehood into thee?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Let it suffice,
I have you, and will hold you prisoner,
As fast as death holds your best props in silence:
We know the hard conditions of our peace,
Slavery or diminution, which we hate
With a joint loathing: may all perish thus
That seek to subjugate or lessen us.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: O the strange nooks of guile or subtlety,
When man so cunningly lies hid from man!
Who could expect such treason from thy breast,
Such thunder from thy voice? or takest thou pride
To imitate the fair uncertainty
Of a bright day, that teems a sudden storm,
When the world least expects one? but of all
I'll never trust fair sky in a man again,
There's the deceitful weather; will you heap
More guilt upon you, by detaining me,
Like a cup taken after a sore surfeit
Even in contempt of health and heaven together?
What seek you?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Ransom for your liberty
As I shall like of, or you never obtain it.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Here's a most headlong dangerous ambition,
Sow you the seeds of your aspiring hopes
In blood and treason, and must I pay for them?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Have not I raised you to this height of pride?
A work of my own merry, since you enforce it.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: There's even the general thanks of all aspirers,
When they have all a kingdom can impart,
They write above it still their own desert.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: I have writ mine true, my lord.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: That's all their sayings.
Have not I raised thy daughter to a Queen?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: You have the harmony of your pleasure for it,
You crown your own desires, what's that to me?

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: And what will crown yours, sir?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Faith things of reason,
I demand Kent.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: Why you've the earldom of it.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: The kingdom of't I mean, without control,
In full possession.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: It seems you're not acquainted with my blood
To call this strange.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Never was King of Kent
But who was general King.

sp.speaker: Heng ▪
sp.l: I'll be the first then,
Every thing has beginning.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Not if you hope for liberty, my lord.
So dear a happiness would not be wronged with slighting.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: Very well, take it, I resign it.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: Is your great thirst yet satisfied?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Faith, my lord,
There's yet behind a pair of teeming sisters,
Norfolk and Suffolk, and I have done with you.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: You've got a dangerous thirst of late, my lord,
Howe'er you came by it.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: It behooves me then
for my blood's health to seek all means to quench it.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: There will nothing be abated, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: You have me at advantage, he whom fate
Does captivate must yield to all; take them.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: And you your liberty and peace, my lord,
With our best love and wishes. Here's an hour
Begins us Saxons in wealth, fame, and power.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Are these the noblest fruits and fairest requitals
From works of our own raising?
Methinks the murder of Constantius
Speaks to me in the voice of it, and the wrongs
Of our late Queen, slipped both into one organ.
Ambition, hell, my own undoing, lust,
And all the brood of plagues conspire against me.
I have not a friend left me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My lord, he dies
That says it but yourself, were't that thief-king
That has so boldly stolen his honours from you,
A treason that wrings tears from honest manhood.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: So rich am I now in thy love and pity
I feel no loss at all; but we must part,
My Queen and I to Cambria.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My lord, and I not named,
That have vowed lasting service to my lives extremest minute?

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: Is my sick fate blessed with so pure a friend!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My lord, no space of earth, nor breadth of sea
Shall divide me from you.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: O faithful treasure!
All my lost happiness is made up in thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I'll follow you through the world, to cuckold you,
That's my way now; every one has his toy
While he lives here; some men delight in building,
A trick of Babel, which will never be left;
Some in consuming what was raised with toiling,
Hengist in getting honour, I in spoiling.

div.head: Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter Symon and his brothers, Aminadab his clerk.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Is not that rebel Oliver, that traitor to my year,
Prehended yet?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Not yet, so please your worship.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Not yet say'st thou? how durst thou say, not yet,
And see me present? thou malapert, that art good for nothing
But to write and read. Is his loom seized upon?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Yes, if it like your worship, and 16 yards of fustian.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Good, let a yard be saved to mend me between the legs,
The rest cut in pieces and given to the poor,
'Tis heretic fustian, and should be burned indeed,
But being worn threadbare the shame will be as great,
How think you neighbours?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Greater methinks the longer it is wore,
Where being once burned it can be burned no more.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: True, wise and most senseless. How now, sirrah,
What's he approaching here in dusty pumps?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: A footman, sir, to the great King of Kent.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: The King of Kent? shake him by the hand for me,
They're welcome, footman, lo, my deputy shakes thee,
Come when my year is out, I'll do't myself.
If 'twere a dog that came from the King of Kent,
I keep those officers would shake him, I trow.
And what's the news with thee, thou well stewed footman?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.l: With a few Saxons,
Intends this night to make merry with you.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Merry with me? I should be sorry else, fellow,
and take it in ill part, so tell Kent's King.
Why was I chosen, but that great men should make
Merry with me? there is a jest indeed;
Tell him, I looked fort't, and me much he wrongs,
If he forget Sym that cutout his thongs.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: I'll run with your worship's answer.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Do I prithee;
That fellow will be roasted against supper,
He's half enough already, his brows baste him.
The King of Kent! the King of Kirsendom
Shall not be better welcome; for you must imagine now, neighbours,
This is the time when Kent stands out of Kirsendom,
For he that's King here now was never kirsened;
This for your more instruction I thought fit,
That when you are dead you may teach your children wit.
Clerk!

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: I must turn you
From the hall to the kitchen tonight . Give order that 12 pigs be
Roasted yellow; 9 geese, and some 3 larks for piddling meat;
And twenty woodcocks, I'll bid all my neighbours;
Give charge the mutton come in all blood-raw, that is infidel's meat,
The King of Kent is a pagan, and must be served so.
And let those officers that seldom, or never go to church
Bring it in, 'twill be the better taken. Run, run, come you hither
Now, take all my cushions down and thwack them soundly,
After my feast of millers; for their buttocks
Have left a peck of flower in them, beat them carefully
Over a bolting hutch, there will be enough
For a pan-pudding, as your dame will handle it.
Then put fresh water into both the bough-pots,
And burn a little juniper in the hall-chimney,
Like a beast as I was, I pissed out the fire last night,
And never dreamt of the Kings coming. How now,
Returned so quickly?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Please your worship here are
A certain company of players.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Country comedians, interluders, sir,
Desire your worship's favour
And leave to enact in the town-hall.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: In the town-hall?
'Tis ten to one I never grant them that;
Call them before my worship.
If my house will not serve their turn, I would fain see
The proudest he lend them a barn:
Now, sirs, are you comedians?

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: We are sir, comedians, tragedians,
Tragi-comedians, comi-tragedians, pastorists,
Humorists, clownists, satirists; we have them sir,
From the hug to the smile, from the smile to the laugh,
From the laugh to the handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: You're very strong in the wrist methinks;
And must all these good parts be cast away
Upon pedlars, and maltmen, ha?

sp.speaker: 1 cheater
sp.p: For want of better company, if it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: What think you of me my masters?
Hum; have you audacity enough
To play before so high a person as myself? will not
My countenance daunt you? for if you play before me
I shall often look on you, I give you that warning before hand,
Take it not ill my masters, I shall laugh at you,
And truly when I am least offended with you;
It is my humour, but be not you abashed.

sp.speaker: 1 cheater
sp.l: Sir, we have played before a lord ere now,
Though we be country actors.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: A lord? ha, ha,
Thou'lt find it a harder thing to please a mayor.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.p: We have a play wherein we use a horse.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Fellows, you use no horseplay in my house,
My rooms are rubbed, keep it for hackney-men.

sp.speaker: 1 cheater
sp.p: We'll not offer it to your worship.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Give me a play without a beast, I charge you.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.p: That's hard, without a cuckold or a drunkard?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: O those beasts are often the best men in a parish,
And must not be kept out. But which is your merriest play?
That I would hearken after.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: Your worship shall hear
Their names, and take your choice.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: And that's plain dealing. Come begin, sir.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.p: The whirligig, the whibble, the carwidgen.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Hey day, what names are these!

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: New names of late.
The wild goose chase.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Is that come up again?
That was a play when I was prentice first.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: Ay, but the cheater has learned more tricks of late,
And gulls the clown with new additions.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Then is your clown a coxcomb, which is he?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Fie, fie, your company
Must fall upon him and beat him, he's too fair i'faith
To make the people laugh ▪

sp.speaker: 1 cheater
sp.p: Not as he may be dressed, sir.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Faith dress him how you will, I'll give him that gift
He will never look half scurvily enough ▪
O the clowns that I have seen in my time!
The very peeping out of one of them would have made
A young heir laugh, though his father lay a dying;
A man undone in law the day before (The saddest case that can be)
Might for his 2d have burst himself with laughing,
And ended all his miseries. Here was a merry world, my masters!
Some talk of things of state, of puling stuff;
There's nothing in a play to a clown,
If he have the grace to hit on it, that's the thing indeed,
The King shows well, but he sets off the King;
But not the King of Kent, I mean not so,
The King is one, I mean, I do not know.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: Your worship speaks with safety, like a rich man,
And for your finding fault, our hopes are greater,
Neither with him the clown, nor me the cheater.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Away then, shift, clown, to thy motley crupper,
We'll see them first, the King shall after supper.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: I commend your worship's wisdom in that, Mr. mayor.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Nay 'tis a point of justice, if it be well examined,
Not to offer the King worse than I'll see myself;
For a play may be dangerous, I have known
A great man poisoned in a play.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: But to what purpose many times I know not.

sp.speaker: Felt.
sp.p: Methinks they should destroy one another so.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: O no no, he that's poisoned is always made privy to it,
That's one good order they have among them. What joyful throat
Is that, Aminadab? what is the meaning of this cry?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Fates I thank you for this victorious day,
Bonfires of peas-straw burn, let the bells ring.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: There's two in mending, and you know they cannot.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Alas the tenor's broken, ring out the treble,
I am overcloyed with joy; welcome thou rebel ▪

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Art thou yet so stout?
Wilt thou not stoop for grace? then get thee out.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: I was not born to stoop but to my loom,
That seized upon, my stooping days are done;
In plain terms, if thou hast any thing to say to me,
Send me away quickly, this is no biding place,
I understand there are players in thy house,
Dispatch me, I charge thee, in the name of all the brothers.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Nay now proud rebel, I will make thee stay,
And to thy greater torment see a play.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: O devil, I conjure thee by Amsterdam.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Our word is past,
Justice may wink a while, but see at last ▪
the play begins, hold, stop him, stop him.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: O that profane trumpet! o, o.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Set him down there I charge you officers.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I'll hide my ears and stop my eyes.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Down with his golls I charge you.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: O tyranny, tyranny, revenge it tribulation!
For rebels there are many deaths, but sure the only way
To execute a Puritan is seeing of a play.
O I shall swoon!

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Which if thou dost, to spite thee,
A player's boy shall bring thee aquavitae.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: O I'll not swoon at all for't, though I die.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Peace, here's a rascal, lift and edify.

sp.speaker: 1 cheater
sp.p: I say still he's an ass that cannot live by his wits.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: What a bold rascal's this? he calls us all asses at first dash,
Sure none of us live by our wits, unless it be Oliver the Puritan.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I scorn as much to live by my wits as the proudest of you all.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Why then you're an ass for company, so hold your prating.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: Fellow in arms, welcome,
The news, the news?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Fellow in arms, quoth he?
He may well call him fellow in arms.
I am sure they're both out at the elbows.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: Be lively, my heart, be lively, the booty is at hand,
He's but a fool of a yeoman's eldest son,
He's balanced on both sides, bully; he's going to buy householdstuff
With one pocket, and to pay rent with the other.

sp.speaker: 1 cheater
sp.l: And if this be his last day, my chuck,
He shall forfeit his lease, quoth the one pocket,
And eat his meat in wooden platters, quoth the other.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Faith then he's not so wise as he ought to be, to let
Such tatterdemallians get the upper hand of him.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: Ay, but smally to our comfort, with both his hands in
His pockets; how is it possible to pick a lock, when the key
Is on the inside of the door?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: O neighbours here's the part now
That carries away the play, if the clown miscarry,
farewell my hopes for ever, the play's spoiled.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: They say there is a foolish kind of thing called a cheater
Abroad, that will gull any yeoman's son of his purse,
And laugh in his face like an Irishman.
I would fain meet with some of these creatures,
I am in as good state to be gulled now as ever I was in my life,
For I have two purses at this time about me, and I would fain be
Acquainted with that rascal that would take one of them now.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Faith thou mayest be acquainted with two or three
That will do their good wills I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: 1 cheater
sp.p: That way's too plain, too easy I am afraid.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: Come, sir, your most familiar cheats take best,
They show like natural things and least suspected,
Give me a round shilling quickly.

sp.speaker: 1 cheater
sp.l: It will fetch
But one of his hands neither, if it take.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: Thou art too covetous, let's have one out first, prithee,
There's time enough to fetch out th'other after.
Thou liest, 'tis lawful currant money.

sp.speaker: 1 cheater
sp.p: I say 'tis copper in some countries.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Here is a fray towards,
But I will hold my hands, let who will part them.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: Copper? I defy thee, and now I shall disprove thee,
Look you, here's an honest yeoman's son of the country,
A man of judgement.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Pray you be covered, sir,
I have eggs in my cap, and cannot put it off.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.p: Will you be tried by him?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: They look rather as if they would be tried next sessions.

sp.speaker: 1 cheater
sp.p: Pray give your judgement of this piece of coin, sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Nay if it be coin you strive about,
Let me see it, I love money.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.p: Let him do his worst, sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Y'had both need wear cut clothes, you're so choleric.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.p: Nay rub it and spare not, sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Now by this silver, gentlemen,
it is good money, would I had a hundred of them.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: We hope well, sir; th'other pocket
And we are made men.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: O neighbours, I begin to be sick of this fool,
To see him thus cozened, I would make his case my own.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Still would I meet with these things called cheaters.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: A whoreson coxcomb, they have met with thee,
I can no longer endure him with patience.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O my rent, my whole years rent!

sp.speaker: Sym ▪
sp.l: A murrain on you,
This makes us landlords stay ▪ so long for our money.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: A scurvy hobby-horse,
That could not leave his money with me, having such a charge
About him; a pox on thee for an ass, thou play a clown?
I will commit thee for offering it; officers, away with him.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: What means your worship? why you'll spoil the play, sir.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Before the King of Kent shall be thus served,
I'll play the clown myself, away with him.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: With me? if it please your worship, 'twas my part.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: But 'twas a foolish part as ever thou play'dst in thy life,
I'll make thee smoke for it, I'll teach thee to understand
To play a clown, thou shalt know, every man
Is not born to it, away with him quickly,
He'll have the other pocket picked else, I heard them say it
With my own ears; see he's come in another disguise
To cheat thee again.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Come on, sir, let us see what your
sp.stage: He throws off his gown, discovering his doublet with a satin forepart and a canvas back
sp.l: Knaveship can do at me now,
You must not think you have a clown in hand,
The fool I have committed too, for playing the part.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Fie, good sir come away,
Will your worship base yourself to play a clown?

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: I beseech your worship let us have our own clown,
I know not how to go forwards else.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Knave, play out thy part with me,
or I'll lay thee by the heels all the days of thy life.
Why how now, my masters, who is that laughed at me?
Cannot a man of worship play the clown a little for his pleasure
But he must be laughed at? do you know who I am?
Is the King's deputy of no better account among you?
Was I chosen to be laughed at? where's my clerk?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Here, if it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Take a note of all those
That laugh at me, that when I have done I may commit them.
Let me see who dare do it now. And now to you once again
Sir cheater, look you, here are my purse-strings, I do defy thee.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: Good sir, tempt me not, my part is so written
That I should cheat your worship if you were my father.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: I should have much joy to have such a rascal to my son.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.l: Therefore I beseech your worship pardon me, the part
Has more knavery in it then when your worship saw it at first,
I assure you you'll be deceived in it, sir, the new additions
Will take any man's purse in Kent or Kirsendom.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: If thou canst take my purse, I'll give it thee freely,
And do thy worst, I charge thee; as thou'lt answer it.

sp.speaker: 2 cheater
sp.p: Say you so? than there's for you, and here is for me:

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: O bless me, neighbours, I am in a fog,
sp.stage: Throws meal in his face, takes his purse, and exit.
sp.l: A cheater's fog, I can see nobody .

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Away, let him go,
He will have all your purses, if he come back,
A pox on your new additions, they spoil all the plays
That ever they come in, the old way had no such roguery in it;
Calls you this a merry comedy, when a man's eyes are put out in't?
Brother Honeysuckle.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: I make you deputy to rule the town till I can see again,
Which will be within these nine days at farthest.
Nothing grieves me now, but that I hear Oliver the rebel
Laugh at me; a pox on your Puritan face, this will make you in
Love with plays as long as you live,
we shall not keep you from them now.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: In sincerity,
I was never better pleased at an exercise. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Neighbours, what colour was the dust
The rascal threw in my face?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: 'Twas meal, if it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Meal? I am glad of it,
I'll hang the miller for selling it.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Nay ten to one
The cheater never bought it, he stole it certainly.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Why then I'll hang the cheater for stealing it,
And the miller for being out of the way when he did it.

sp.speaker: Felt:
sp.l: I but your worship was in the fault yourself,
You bid him do his worst.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: His worst? that's true,
But the rascal hath done his best; for I know not how a villain
Could put out a man's eyes better, and leave them in his head,
As he has done mine.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: How now Aminadab? I hear thee though I see thee not.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: You are sure cozened, sir, they are all professed cheaters,
They have stolen two silver spoons, and the clown took his heels
With all celerity; they only take the name of country-comedians
To abuse simple people with a printed play or two,
Which they bought at Canterbury for six pence,
And what is worse, they speak but
What they list of it, and fribble out the rest.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Here's no abuse to the commonwealth,
If a man could see to look into it,
But mark the cunning of these cheating slaves,
First they make justice blind, then play the knaves.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Od's precious brother, the King of Kent is newly alighted ▪

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: The King of Kent? where is he,
That I should live to this day,
And yet not live to see to bid him welcome?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: Where is Simonides, our friendly host?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Ah blind as one that had been foxed a seven-night ▪

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Faith practising a clown's part for your grace
I have practised both my eyes out.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: A man is never too old to learn, your grace will say so,
When you hear the jest of it; the truth is, my lord, I meant
To have been merry, and now it is my luck to weep
Water and oatmeal; I shall see again at supper,
I make no doubt of it.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: This is strange to me, sirs.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: With swiftest speed, if ever you'll behold
The Queen your daughter alive again.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: They are besieged, Aurelius,
Ambrose, and his brother Uther,
With numbers infinite of British forces,
Beset their castle, and they cannot scape
Without your speedy succour.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: For her safety I'll forget food and rest: away.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: I hope your worship will hear the jest ere you go.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: I'll follow you to Wales with a dog and a bell
But I will tell it you.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: 'Tis sign of war when great men disagree;
Look to the rebel well, till I can see,
And when my sight is recovered, I will have
His eyes pulled out for a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: My eyes? hang thee,
A deadly sin or two shall pluck them out first,
That is my resolution. Ha, ha, ha.

div.head: Act. 5. Scaena 2.
div.stage: Enter Aurelius and Uther with soldiers, (Vortiger and Horsus above.)

sp.speaker: Uther.
sp.p: My lord, the castle is so fortified.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Let wildfire ruin it,
That his destruction may appear to him
In the figure of heaven's wrath at the last day,
That murderer of our brother. Hence away,
I'll send my heart no peace till it be consumed.

sp.speaker: Uth.
sp.p: There he appears again, behold, my lord.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O that the zealous fire on my soul's altar,
To the high birth of virtue consecrated,
Would fit me with a lightning now to blast him,
Even as I look upon him.

sp.speaker: Uth.
sp.l: Good my lord,
Your anger is too noble and too precious
To waste itself on guilt so foul as his;
Let ruin work her will.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: All, all, my lord, 'tis folly to make doubt of it,
You question things that horror long ago
Resolved us on.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Do what you will, sir, question them again,
I'll tell them to you.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Not so, sir,
I will not have them told again ▪

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: That's an ill word put in, when thy heart knows
There is no rest at all, but torment making.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: True, my heart finds it; that sits weeping blood now
For poor Roxena's safety. You'll confess, my lord,
My love to you has brought me to this danger?
I could have lived like Hengist, King of Kent,
London, York, Lincoln, and Winchester,
Under the power of my command, the portion
Of my most just desert, enjoyed now
By pettier, deservers.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Say you so, sir,
And you'll confess? since you began confession
(A thing I should have died ere I had thought on)
You've married the fashion of your affection utterly,
In your own wicked counsel, there you paid me,
You were bound in conscience to love me after,
You were bound to't, as men in honesty,
That vitiate virgins, to give dowries to them;
My faith was pure before to a faithful woman.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Why I'll be judged by these
That knit death in their brows, and hold me now
Not worth the acception of a flattery,
Most of whose faces smiled when I smiled once; my lords:

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Seeds of scorn, I mind you not,
I speak to them alone whose force makes yours a power,
Which else were none. Show me the main food of your hate,
Which cannot be the murder of Constantius
That crawls in your revenges; for your loves
Were violent long since that.

sp.speaker: 1 lo.
sp.l: And had been still,
If from that pagan wound th'hadst kept thee free,
But when thou fled'st from heaven, we fled from thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Mine? 'twas the counsel
Of your own lust and blood, your appetite knows it.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: May thunder strike me from these walls, my lords,
And leave me many leagues off from your eyes,
If this be not the man, whose Stygian soul
breathed forth that counsel to me, and sole plotter
Of all those false injurious disgraces
That have abused the virtuous patience
Of our religious Queen.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Upon whose life, I swear, there sticks no stain
But what's most wrongful, and where now she thinks
A rape dwells on her honour, only I
Her ravisher was, and his the policy.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Now you know the truth,
Will his death serve your fury?

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: It shall, speak but the word, it shall be yielded up.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Believe him not, he cannot do it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Tis but a false and base insinuation
For his own life, and like his late submission.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: O sting to honour, alive or dead thou goest
For that words rudeness only.

sp.speaker: 1 lo.
sp.l: See, sin needs
No other destruction than it breeds in its own bosom.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What, has thy vile rage stamped a wound upon me?
I've send one to thy soul shall never heal for't.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It shall be thy master-torment
Both for the pain and the everlastingness.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Dost laugh? take leave of it, all eternity
Shall never see thee do so much again:
Know thou'rt a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You change too soon, sir.
Roxena, whom thou'st raised to thy own ruin,
She was my whore in Germany.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: Burst me open the violence of whirlwinds:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Hear me out first,
For her embrace, which my flesh yet sits warm in,
I was thy friend and follower.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Deafen me
Thou most imperious noise that starts the world!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And to serve both our lusts I practised with thee
Against thy virtuous Queen.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Whose faithful sweetness, too precious for thy blood,
I made thee change for love's hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Only to make my way to pleasure fearless, free and fluent.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: Hell's trump is in that throat.

div.stage: They stab each other. Rox. enters in fear.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: I'll dam it up with death first.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: O for succour!
Who's near me? help me, save me, the flame follows me,
'Tis in the figure of young Vortimer, the prince,
Whose life I took by poison.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Hold out breath and I shall find thee quickly.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: I'll tug thy soul out here.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: O hear me,
O help me, my love, my lord, 'tis here,
Horsus look up, if not to succour me,
To see me yet consumed; o what is love
When life is not regarded?

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: What strength's left I'll fix upon thy throat.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: No way to scape? is this the end of glory?
Doubly beset with enemy's wrath and fire:
It comes nearer, rivers and fountains fall,
It sucks away my breath, I cannot give
A curse to sin, and hear't out while I live. Help, help.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.l: Burn, burn, now I can tend thee,
Take time with her in torment, call her life
Afar off to thee, dry up her strumpet-blood,
And hard y parch the skin, let one heat strangle her,
Another fetch her to her sense again,
And the worst pain be only her reviving,
Follow her eternally; o mystical harlot,
Thou hast thy full due, whom lust crowned Queen before
Flames crown her now a most triumphant whore.
And that end crowns them all.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Our peace is full,
In you usurpers fall, nor have I known
A judgement meet more fearfully.
Here, take this ring, deliver the good Queen,
And those grave pledges of her murthered honour,
(Her worthy father, and her noble uncle.)
How now ▪ the meaning of these sounds?

div.stage: Enter Hengist, Devon. staf. And soldiers.

sp.speaker: Heng ▪
sp.l: The consumer has been here, she's gone, she's lost,
In glowing cinders now lie all my joys,
The headlong fortune of my rash captivity
Strikes not so deep a wound into my hopes
As thy dear loss.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Part of my wishes,
What fortunate power has prevented me,
And ere my love came, brought them victory?

sp.speaker: 1 lo.
sp.p: My wonder sticks in Hengist King of Kent.

sp.speaker: Devon.
sp.l: My lord, to make that plain which now I see
Fixed in astonishment; the only name
Of your return and being brought such gladness
To this distracted kingdom, that, to express
A thankfulness to heaven, it grew great
In charitable actions, from which goodness
we taste our liberty, who lived engaged
Upon the innocence of woman's honour,
(A kindness that even threatened to undo us)
And having newly but enjoyed the benefit
And fruits of our enlargement, 'twas our happiness
To intercept this monster of ambition,
Bred in these times of usurpation,
The rankness of whose insolence and treason
Grew to such height, 'twas armed to bid you battle.
Whom, as our fame's redemption, on our knees
We present captive.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Had it needed reason
You richly came provided, I understood
Not your deserts till now; my honoured lords,
Is this that German Saxon, whose least thirst
Could not be satisfied under a province?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Had but my fate directed this bold arm
To thy life, the whole kingdom had been mine,
That was my hopes great aim; I have a thirst
Could never have been full quenched under all,
The whole must do't or nothing.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: A strange draught!
And what a little ground shall death now teach you
To be content withal?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Why let it then,
For none else can, you've named the only way
To limit my ambition, a full cure
For all my fading hopes and sickly fears;
Nor shall it be less we come to me now
Then a fresh acquisition would have been
Unto my new built kingdoms; life to me,
( 'Less it be glorious) is a misery.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: That pleasure we will do you; lead him out,
And when we have inflicted our just doom
On his usurping head, it will become
Our pious care to see this realm secured
From the convulsions it hath long endured.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
